title: Base class for Turing Machine, LL Parser, PDA?
body: Misschien is het handig om een base class te maken voor de Turing Machine, LL Parser en PDA die een virtual function 'bool process()' heeft. Dan kunnen we achteraf eenvoudig wisselen tussen deze 3?

title: SymbolString is std::string
body:
I've removed the class `SymbolString` and change that to `typedef std::string SymbolString` instead. Because for my CNF, I **really** need string iterators. 

Additionally, it's pointless to create an apart class `SymbolString` since it's just really an ordinary string consisting of symbols that is either in the set of the variables and/or in the set of terminals.

You can check it out there:
https://github.com/rubenvanassche/RNA-Stem-Loop-Visualizer/blob/master/src/CFG.h#L33

title: Code clean up
body:
I've implemented the following stuffs, but needs to be cleaned up (refactorizing) and deeply tested: the tests are too weak to guarantee that it works as the way as we expect, but _on the top_ it seems they are working. **But there's no guarantee (yet) they actually works. Use it at your own risk.**
- [x] `std::set<SymbolString> CFG::productions(const char& v) const;`
- [x] `std::set<char> CFG::nullable() const;`
- [x] `void CFG::eleminateEpsilonProductions();`
- [x] `std::set< std::pair<char, char> > CFG::units() const;`
- [x] `void CFG::eleminateUnitProductions();`
- [x] `std::set<char> CFG::generating() const;`
- [x] `std::set<char> CFG::reachable() const;`
- [x] `void CFG::eleminateUselessSymbols();`
- [x] `void CFG::cleanUp();`

They are currently available in the `master` branch, but remember: **in BÃ¨ta mode** until I've closed this issue. The contracts however, remains the same.

Now let's enjoy of my fresh :beer: first, before I'll do this!

Also: please report bugs if there are some failures in your tests and you think it comes from one of the methods from the list above.

title: Detecting cyclic unit pairs
body:
Well.. not really a bug, but is quit painful to fix this:

remark on: https://github.com/rubenvanassche/RNA-Stem-Loop-Visualizer/blob/master/src/CFG.cpp#L288

This should throw an `std::logic_error` in case there appears any cyclic unit pairs in the set of unit pairs of the CFG, because the `eleminateUnitProductions()` will then not work. I haven't checked it (yet) what should happen if I put a CFG with cyclic unit pairs in it. I guess this will result in unpredictable behavior. I'll ask Prof. Laenens or Tom what will happen if I do so.

The algorithm for checking whether there's a cyclic unit pairs in it, is quite painful I think, I've posted this question in [stackoverflow](http://stackoverflow.com/questions/20054637/detecting-cyclic-pairs)

I'll get on this when enough time is left. (or if somebody else could solve it, should be great too :-) )

title: CYK algorithm

title: std::set instead of std::multimap for CFG
body:
For CFG's, I want to change the `std::multimap<char, SymbolString> fProductions` into the `std::map<char, std::set<SymbolString> > fProductions`. The reason I want to do this is 
1. I often need the whole set of bodies from a certain variable in a certain production instead of just one.
2. The `std::multimap` allows to have duplicate key-value pairs, (e.g. the key-value pair (A, BC) appears multiple times in the `std::multimap`) leaving my CNF with an exponential blow-up size, (some of my tests indicated that, a simple set of production rules resulted in 25% original key-value pairs and the other 75% were just duplicates of other keys!) which doesn't really make sense. It will just slowdown the CNF-constructing and the CYK-algorithm.
3. The `std::map<char, std::set<SymbolString>>` will make the implementation (of CNF and CYK + CFG) much simplier and more efficient

The `std::map<char, std::set<SymbolString>>` will solve both issues.

I hope everyone aggrees? If not, please reply and I'll rewind it back :wink:

title: Optimizing flags for G++
body: Using one of the optimizing flags for G++ (-O1, -O2, -O3) makes some of my tests fail, though all succeed without optimizing flags. Does anyone know why those flags might cause that?

title: Mac OSx segmentation fault
Workshops
body:
For the workshops in two days, the other teams have to be able to test our Phase I. I guess we should each add a separate executable (and thus main()) to provide easy testing for our own implementation.
Mine would be something like this: a ManualTuringTest executable, which takes the name of a Turing Machine in .xml form as a command line argument. Then the executable asks the user for a string, and prints whether the string was accepted by the Turing Machine.

If you support input files containing your CFG/PDA/Parser in XML format (or whatever format you prefer), you should probably do something similar to my executable. However, if you do not support this and do not feel like adding it either, the best thing would be to write an example CFG/PDA/Parser in your main(), so that the other teams can edit it and recompile to test.

I think this was due last Friday, so you should do this ASAP

However none of the other teams have uploaded anything, so we're not totally fucked ;)
(And maybe don't go asking the other teams just yet, if they forget, we don't have to prepare anything for their implementations! :D )
